body:
@bolkedebruin, thanks for the clean up.

To address your comment on #2975, I believe `root_process` of the task_runner is always the `--raw` task. In `base_task_runner.py`, I see that the command to spin up the process always have raw set to True:
```
        self._command = popen_prepend + self._task_instance.command_as_list(
            raw=True,
            pickle_id=local_task_job.pickle_id,
            mark_success=local_task_job.mark_success,
            job_id=local_task_job.id,
            pool=local_task_job.pool,
            cfg_path=cfg_path,
        )
```
I agree with you that it doesn't make sense to have the root process killing itself, and your PR addresses this with:
```
if pid == os.getpid():
    raise RuntimeError("I refuse to kill myself")
```

In addition, I think we should delete the signal handler in the [`--raw` task process](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1541-L1546). I'm not sure why it's there to begin with, but like you said, we shouldn't be letting root process attempting to kill itself.
@bolkedebruin I don't have any religion about uuid/guid, simplified as uid out of habit.  I'll change it to uuid to be consistent with convention.
Updated to uuid.  Thanks @bolkedebruin for the feedback.
@Fokko any issues with merging?   Build failure not related to code change.

Thanks again @Fokko! I've rebased onto master but the TravisCI build failed and I don't have permissions to restart it. It also happened to the build triggered on my forked repo but it was fine after restarting it so I'd say the underlying issues when building are not related with this PR. Below you can find a link to the build on my repo:

https://travis-ci.org/sdiazb/airflow/builds/364328340?utm_source=email&utm_medium=notification

Could you restart the build or do you recommend me to create a new PR which will trigger a new build? Any other alternative?

Thanks in advance.
And I just did a rebase, and made it flake8 compatible...

@dlebech I have a pending PR ([AIRFLOW-2291](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2746)) that would benefit from this too. A bit of rework and cleanup of the operator as well.
But I didn't address one comment as other operators :) and DAGs came up; although I just commented to the reviewer.
Not sure what is the best approach here @Fokko. My PR could include this PR as I address parameters too (although with a focus on templating) and at the same time I also did some cleanup in the operators.
But I don't want @dlebech to have to fix conflicts nor myself :)

@johnarnold sorry to get back on this so late. 

Just realized that in the case where there is no impersonation, all the environment variables are _already_ being passed down to the task execution process, which means they are already accessible to all operators. This PR simply extends this behavior when user impersonation is specified. 

That said, I share the same concern as @Fokko, I still believe we have a potential security concern on the whole by passing down all environment variables to the local task execution. This means that it is the responsibility of (1) the airflow admin to not store sensitive data in environment variables in production or (2) the dag repo maintainer to properly audit the dag file and make sure it is not malicious. (1) seems very hard to guarantee (2) seems easier, but not foolproof.

I'm okay with merging this PR since it's just extending existing behavior. Long term I think we should address this issue, so I'll create a [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2311) for this.
Commented, and please add unit test and follow the PR guideline. Thanks!

Hi @jgao54 

Im not sure if deleting the signal handler from the —raw task is the right thing to do. The signal handler is there to trigger the on_kill method of the operator. If absent that would not be run anymore. bashOperator and the SparkSubmitOperator both make use of this.

On your comment of the “root” process. I don’t think you are correct and your implementation worked by coincidence. If you run “bash -c sleep 1000”, you will find ‘sleep’ in your process list but you won’t find ‘bash’ running anymore. However the parent pid of sleep still refers to the pid of bash. So your implementation worked in case of a TaskRunner that used something like bash to execute the command. If you would you “sleep” directly (so without bash) you would get ourselves as the parent of the “sleep” process and thus kill yourself.

Using setsid makes sure we Airflow sees all processes to the new session/group regardless. Except when they run setsid themselves, which happens for example in the BashOperator. The bashOperator therefore becomes responsible for cleaning up after itself.

Thanks for sharing your code and investigation @Mokubyow!
I'm afraid I'm not sure yet if your workaround solves this problem fundamentally, since there seems to be no operation which detaches DagModel object from the session (e.g. expunge) or expires its attributes (e.g. expire or commit) up to [the line in question](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/api/common/experimental/delete_dag.py#L48). Let me have a bit more time to specify the root cause (it may be session expiration, as you said) and make it reproducible so as to write unit test and fix it fundamentally.

@wileeam It seems to be that my PR contains such as a small change, and it doesn't really interfere with your PR (mine simply adds a few parameters to the traning operator, not the prediction operator), so I don't know what benefit there is to try and merge the two PRs? But anyway, that's not my call, so I'll be happy just to see this change in Airflow no matter what path it takes to get there :-)

@aoen @saguziel @Fokko PTAL
@Fokko I've opened again the [old PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2522) to force the build. I think everything is ready to be merged now. Many thanks for your help.

> Im not sure if deleting the signal handler from the —raw task is the right thing to do.

You are correct, silly of me. Looks like that's the only place operator on_kill method is triggered (I somehow remembered that TaskRunner upon termination will explicitly call operator.on_kill, but that's not the case at all)

> However the parent pid of sleep still refers to the pid of bash.

I believe when `bash -c` stops running, `sleep 1000`'s parent id will get reassigned to the grandparent (or nearest ancestor).

Perhaps there's a bit of misunderstanding on `root process`. What I meant by the "root process" is the `process` attribute in the TaskRunner, which is always the pid of `airflow run --raw` process, while reap_process_group method (executed in `airflow run --local` process) takes in that pid as "root process". So I think having "root process kill itself" scenario is not possible after all (?). 

This is just mostly me thinking out loud. The setsid makes sense to me and so does this PR,  but i'm still a bit lost with the whole picture.

@jgao54 

> I believe when bash -c stops running, sleep 1000's parent id will get reassigned to the grandparent (or nearest ancestor).

I verified this (on a mac) and that is not the case. The parent PID is just not there anymore.

> while reap_process_group method (executed in airflow run --local process) takes in that pid as "root process". So I think having "root process kill itself" scenario is not possible after all (?).

`reap_process_group` does not really care about the `root process`. It could take any of the PIDs and get the GPID from there. By coincidence/convention when you call `setsid` the OS (POSIX) sets the GPID to the PID of the process that is the leader of the group. In `reap_process_group` we only add the parent pid to ensure we can watch all processes in the process group otherwise we could quit right away thinking we are done.

Not a big fan of this. Did you look into the `>>` notation?
Nah dont like it either.

Not a fan of ` >> ` @Fokko but thanks, yes aware of it though.

Point is a.set_upstream(b) could mean either
  1. "Take a, and set b upstream of it."
  2. "Take a, and set it upstream of b."

Both seem completely reasonable syntactically.

@sekikn I added a parameter called include_header. Only if this is true, header will be included part of the file. Also, if include_header is true then `PARALLEL OFF` command will be automatically included if it was not provided in unload_options
@Fokko Now I understood what you meant. :) I made the changes. Please review it. Thanks.

> I added a parameter called include_header. Only if this is true, header will be included part of the file.

Thanks for updating @sathyaprakashg, that's really nice improvement. I confirmed that both of include_header=True and False work as expected with a real Redshift cluster.
Just one comment, defaulting include_header=False changes the default behaviour and introduces backward incompatibility, so would you add an entry about that to UPDATING.md? +1 other than that.

To provide a bit of a background on this ticket:

MySqlToGCS operator has a default mapping of mysql field_type to BigQuery type, specified in the `type_map` classmethod in this operator. 

Unfortunately, with mysqldb client in PY2, it turns out to be very difficult to discern between VARBINARY and VARCHAR, they will both return as FIELD_TYPE.VARCHAR in mysqldb client (similarly, between CHAR/BINARY, BLOB/TEXT), so in the past, all binary fields in mysql were mapped to String. There is a binary flag returned by the cursor,  which we originally attempted to use to discern the types. However if binary collation is on, then the binary flag will be set to true regardless of the field type. 

The work-around is to allow user to provide custom `schema` as an operator argument, so that it can override the default mapping. And if it's specified as a binary field, it will be base64 encoded, since binary types in BQ is required to be base64 encoded.
